sections.purpose: To describe the standard operating procedure for the operation of Gas Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry (GC-MS) for identification, structural elucidation, and quantitative analysis of volatile pharmaceutical compounds.
sections.scope: Applicable to GC-MS analysis activities carried out in the Central Instrumentation.
procedure: Verify that the vacuum system is functioning and the roughing pump oil level is adequate.
Check carrier gas (helium) supply and ensure adequate pressure and purity.
Power ON the mass spectrometer and allow the vacuum system to reach operating pressure.
Power ON the GC system and data acquisition software after vacuum stabilization.
Perform tuning and calibration of the mass spectrometer using calibration standard.
Verify that tuning report shows acceptable sensitivity and mass accuracy.
Set carrier gas flow rate, injector temperature, and column oven program.
Set MS parameters including scan range, ionization mode, and source temperature.
Allow the entire system to stabilize for at least 30 minutes.
Run a blank injection to check for background contamination and baseline stability.
Prepare sample and standard solutions in appropriate GC-compatible solvents.
Inject standard solutions and verify chromatographic separation and mass spectral quality.
Acquire full scan or selected ion monitoring (SIM) data as per analytical requirements.
Inject sample solutions and monitor both chromatogram and mass spectra.
Perform library search for compound identification using spectral databases.
Verify retention times and mass spectral patterns against reference standards.
After analysis, allow the column to cool and perform system cleaning if needed.
Power OFF the GC system first, then initiate mass spectrometer shutdown sequence.
Wait for the system to vent before powering off completely.
Save all data files with proper identification and document in the logbook.
precautions: Always ensure proper vacuum levels before operating the MS detector.
Never turn off the vacuum pump while the MS is hot to prevent contamination.
Use high purity carrier gas (helium, 99.999%) for optimal MS performance.
Ensure samples are clean and free from non-volatile residues that can contaminate the ion source.
Do not inject water or highly polar solvents that may damage the MS system.
Monitor filament current and replace filaments when sensitivity decreases.
Clean the ion source regularly to maintain sensitivity and mass accuracy.
Use appropriate PPE when handling samples and solvents.
Perform regular maintenance including pump oil changes and leak checks.
